Award.AwardTitle: The use of high-frequency data to engage students in quantitative reasoning and scientific discourse

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing modules that introduce quantitative activities based on large, long-term and sensor-based systems for undergraduates at a diverse suite of institutions.

Intellectual merit: This project is developing the skills required to manipulate large datasets at different scales while improving the students' reasoning skills by engaging them in authentic research experiences. The project's methods are designed to sharpen the highly transferable skills (i.e., data integration, statistical proficiency and analysis) necessary for doing science in the digital age. Online datasets supported by National Atmospheric Deposition Program, Global Lake Ecological Observatory network (GLEON) and the National Snow and Ice Data Center, among others, will be used to develop a framework for modules that yield important ecological information for the biological community while providing engaging experiences with authentic data for the undergraduate students at a variety of academic institutions.

Broader impacts: From an educational perspective, this project provides an opportunity for undergraduates from a diverse group of schools to partake in analyses on authentic data provided from national centers on real and pressing environmental issues. Assessment of the project focuses on the effects of the modules on competency in inquiry, quantitative reasoning, and students' ability to conduct scientific discourse. The project also represents a collaboration of scientists in a range of environmental disciplines and career stages brought together by a common desire to improve undergraduate student experience and learning.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts toward support of Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because of increases in computer power and the availability of environmental sensors, large datasets are becoming more common. Working with long-term and high-frequency datasets is evoking new ways of doing science. Analyzing large datasets requires skills that are not commonly taught in undergraduate curricula.

We developed ten modules that use large datasets in geology, hydrology, environmental science, and aquatic ecology. Each module uses a dataset that is too large to manipulate easily and most datasets are publically available online. Modules focus on having students explore the data graphically and quantitatively to address scientific concepts within that discipline. Their structure is flexible, and the format can be modified depending upon the course level and the amount of time available.

We used these modules in a wide range of courses, from introductory to graduate students, and across eight different institutions, including a small private liberal arts college, mid-sized state universities, and large research-intensive universities. We assessed the modules by administering surveys before and after the module, asking students to report their comfort and competence with Excel skills and to describe how they would address a hypothetical research question, following accepted methods in science education research.

We found that students showed significant (self-reported) improvements in Excel skills after using only one module. Student also appeared to have a greater appreciation for large datasets, computer software, and models, and working with the modules did help students develop a stronger understanding of the scientific concepts involved in the module. Gains from using the module seem to occur even when the students do not work through the modules specifically in class, suggesting that the modules are just as effective when assigned as homework and have the potential to be used for online courses. The broader conceptual approach used in module development, which has been described in a few of our publications, can be applied to develop modules in disciplines beyond those in our study.
